Early Settlement and Coastal Significance:

  • Part of Ancient Guangdong: The area that is now Shanwei, including the Red Sea Bay, has been inhabited for a long time. Before the Qin Dynasty (221-206 BC), the region was home to various tribal groups known collectively as the Baiyue.
  • Under Imperial China: During the Qin and Han dynasties, the area fell under the administration of Nanhai Shire. The coastline of this region has always held significance for fishing and potentially small-scale trade.
  • Migration and Ethnic Groups: The dominant ethnic group in Shanwei today is Hoklo (Minnan speakers), who largely migrated to the area during the early Qing Dynasty (17th century) due to population decreases caused by warfare elsewhere. These communities would have established fishing villages and livelihoods along the coast, including what is now Red Sea Bay.

Historical Administration:

  • Part of Huizhou: For a long period under the Ming and Qing empires, the Shanwei area, including Red Sea Bay, was administratively part of the larger Huizhou Prefecture (惠州府).
  • Gaining Independence: It wasn’t until the Nationalist period in the 20th century that Shanwei gained prefectural and administrative independence from Huizhou. Shanwei City was officially established in 1988.

Red Sea Bay’s Natural Features and Traditional Uses:

  • Fishing Grounds: The coastline of Shanwei, with its bays and inlets like Red Sea Bay, has historically been a significant fishing ground, supporting local communities for centuries.
  • Natural Harbor Potential: The presence of the Zhelangjiao peninsula, creating calmer waters on one side of Red Sea Bay, would have offered natural shelter for smaller vessels over time.
  • Naming: The name “Red Sea Bay” (Honghaiwan) likely refers to the reddish hues that can often be seen in the sky during sunrise and sunset in the area, a phenomenon that has probably inspired local folklore.

Modern Development:

  • Tourism and Recreation: In more recent times, particularly in the late 20th and early 21st centuries, the natural beauty of Red Sea Bay, with its beaches and clear waters, has led to its development as a tourist destination.
  • Surfing Hotspot: Notably, Red Sea Bay has become known as a surfing paradise, with consistent waves attracting enthusiasts. This development seems to have gained momentum in the early 2000s through the efforts of local entrepreneurs who recognized the bay’s potential.

The presence of charging stations suggests a move towards supporting modern transportation needs related to tourism and local development.
  • Filming Location: The scenic landscapes of Red Sea Bay, particularly around the Zhelangjiao peninsula, have made it a popular location for shooting movies and television shows.
